text: Stalls lined both sides of the street — grilled fish, spices, and flowers mingled with the scent of cooking smoke.
The rhythmic clang of the blacksmith’s hammer echoed through the air, blending with chatter and the wind into a warm kind of bustle.
“I thought you could barely walk, but look at you—you’re faster than me.”
I looked toward a grilled fish stall. “That smell should be illegal.”
Alicia sighed in mild exasperation but still followed me to the stand.
She pulled out a few coins. “One’s for him.”
I paid before she could stop me. The vendor handed over the skewers with a smile, and the smoky aroma filled the air.
Alicia blinked, accepting her skewer, and glanced at me curiously.
“Since when did you become so considerate?”
“Well, someone did save my life. Figured I should return the favor somehow.”
She gave a quiet laugh and said nothing more.
Sunlight brushed across her face; the scent of grilled fish drifted on the breeze — a fleeting, yet unmistakably peaceful moment.
